title-group.article-title: Induction of Senescence During Postpartum Mammary Gland Involution supports tissue remodeling and promotes postpartum tumorigenesis

contrib-group.aff: 1Cellular plasticity in age-related pathologies, Dept. of Developmental & Stem Cell Biology, https://ror.org/02feahw73CNRS UMR 3738, https://ror.org/05f82e368Université Paris Citéhttps://ror.org/0495fxg12Institut Pasteur, 25 rue du Dr Roux, Paris75015, France

fn.p: Current address: Department of Ophthalmology, Shanghai General Hospital, Shanghai, 200080, China

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Cellular senescence is an evolutionarily conserved stress response1, yet its roles during physiological processes remain underexplored2,3. Senescent cells are known to promote tissue repair4,5 and suppress tumorigenesis6, but their accumulation contributes to various pathological and physiological processes, including cancer and ageing7–9. However, it is currently unknown whether physiological senescence can be co-opted by oncogenic events to promote tumorigenesis. Postpartum mammary gland involution is a major tissue remodelling event in adulthood10,11, resembling the wound healing process, and is closely linked to postpartum breast cancer (PPBC)12 providing a compelling context to investigate this question. Here, we show that senescence is induced in alveolar luminal cells during involution in a p16-dependent manner. Reducing senescent cells hinders tissue remodeling and delays involution, underscoring their physiological importance. However, using a PPBC mouse model where the oncogenic event coincides with involution, we demonstrate that eliminating involution-associated senescent cells markedly extended the cancer latency. Mechanistically, we reveal that senescent cells enhance tumor-initiating cell plasticity in a paracrine manner, promoting tumor invasion and metastasis. Collectively, our findings uncover a dual role of senescence in mediating postpartum tissue remodeling and promoting tumorigenesis, highlighting a scenario where physiological senescence is hijacked to drive cancer progression. This work underscores that senescence might be a unifying mechanism linking tissue repair to tumorigenesis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cellular senescence is a stress-induced cell state characterized by stable cell cycle arrest, resistance to apoptosis, and a robust secretome known as senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP)7,9. However, senescence is not a uniform identity as previously viewed, it is now recognized as a highly heterogeneous phenotypes and pleiotropic functions that vary depending on cell type origin, inducers, and tissue context1. The stable cell cycle arrest is a potent cell-intrinsic tumour suppression mechanism 6, yet contributes to diminished regenerative capacity and tissue dysfunction during aging13. Extrinsically, senescent cells modulate extensively the microenvironment by secreting SASP factors and presenting cell-surface proteins14,15. The functional duality positions senescence as a key player in numerous physiological and pathological processes7,9, including embryonic development16,17, tissue repair4,5, fibrosis18–20, cancer8, and ageing21. Importantly, targeted elimination of senescent cells can delay the onset and improve many ageing-associated pathologies22–24. Despite extensive research into the pathological roles of senescence, its functional contributions to normal physiology remain poorly understood2,3. Furthermore, it remains unclear whether physiological senescence can be hijacked by oncogenic processes to drive tumorigenesis.

The postpartum period involve extensive physiological changes with lasting implications for women’s health25,26. Among these, the mammary gland undergoes dramatic remodeling during postpartum involution, a process that returns the gland to its pre-pregnant state after lactation (or directly after pregnancy if lactation does not occur)10. During this process, all the newly formed lobuloalveolar structures generated during pregnancy are removed via apoptosis and lysosomal-mediated cell death27–32. Concurrently, the gland undergoes extensive remodeling of the extracellular matrix, blood vessels, and adipocytes refilling, companied by a strong inflammatory response and immune infiltration33–40, to restore mammary epithelium integrity. Of note, mammary involution resembles a scarless wound-healing process as the mammary epithelium after involution can respond properly to the subsequent pregnancy and lactation repetitively throughout female’s reproductive life span.

While involution is critical for mammary gland homeostasis and the successful establishment of future lactation11, it also create a transient pro-tumorigenic microenvironment12 and is strongly implicated in postpartum breast cancer (PPBC), defined as breast cancer diagnosed within 5–10 years after childbirth41–43. PPBC is associated with higher metastasis rates and poorer survival compared to nulliparous women or those diagnosed during pregnancy, regardless of hormone receptor status41–43. Notably, increased maternal age positively correlates with a higher incidence of PPBC44. With the global trend of delayed childbirth, PPBC incidence and mortality rates are expected to rise significantly, emphasizing a critical unmet medical need. However, the mechanisms underlying the pro-tumorigenic features of involution remain not well understood.

Here, we provide evidence that certain alveolar luminal cells upregulate p16 to acquire senescence state during postpartum mammary gland involution. Loss-of-functions studies reveal that senescence is required for proper tissue remodelling during involution but, paradoxically, also promotes tumorigenesis and metastasis in a paracrine manner by enhancing tumour-initiating cells plasticity. Thus, our findings demonstrate that in a physiological context like mammary gland involution, senescence plays a dual role both mediating tissue remodeling and facilitating tumorigenesis and suggesting that senescence might serve as a common mechanism linking wound healing to cancer.

sec.title: Cellular senescence is transiently induced at the onset of the tissue remodeling phase of mammary gland (MG) involution
sec.p: To investigate whether senescence occurs throughout MG postnatal development and the reproductive cycle, we performed senescence-associated beta-galactosidase (SA-βGal) staining on murine MGs collected at various developmental stages, including puberty (6 weeks), mature virgin (10 weeks), pregnancy (p13.5 and p18.5), lactation (lac10), and involution (Figure 1A). Notably, robust SA-βGal staining was observed in involuting MGs, while SA-βGal+ cells were scarcely detectable at other stages (Figure 1B). The involution process in rodents consists two morphologically distinct phases10. During the first 48 hours, programmed cell death occurs, while the alveolar lumen remains intact. This is followed by a phase of extensive tissue remodeling between 60 and 72 hours, characterized by alveolar regression and adipocyte repopulation10. To analyze the dynamics of SA-βGal+ cells during involution, we initiated synchronized involution by removing pups after 10 days of lactation and collected MGs at different time points: Inv1, Inv3, Inv7, Inv14, and Inv28 (representing the resting MG) (Figure 1A). Interestingly, SA-βGal+ cells became apparent starting at Inv3, with staining intensity peaking at Inv7 and gradually diminishing thereafter (Figure 1C, i-iv). No SA-βGal+ cells were detected in the resting MG following the completion of involution (Inv28, Figure 1C, v). Most SA-βGal staining was spatially restricted to the alveolar region compared to the ductal epithelium.

To further validate our observations and characterize the senescence program associated with mammary gland involution, we conducted bulk RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) on MGs from Inv0, Inv3, and Inv7. Principal component analysis (PCA) revealed clear clustering of Inv0, Inv3, and Inv7 samples, indicating distinct biological differences across these stages (Figure 1D). Gene-set enrichment analysis (GSEA) demonstrated significant enrichment of senescence-associated genes45 in both Inv3 and Inv7 compared to Inv0 (Figure 1E). Heatmap depicting upregulated senescence-associated genes in Inv3 and Inv7 relative to Inv0 further highlighted this senescence signature (Supplementary Figure 1A). Interestingly, we identified numerous genes crucial for the involution process, including extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling factors such as MMP2, MMP3, MMP14, and Serpine136,37; cytokines and chemokines46 like CXCL12, CXCL10, CCL4, CXCL16, CCL3, CCL2, IL18, and CCL8; and growth factors37,47, including GDF15, FGF2/7, and IGFBP4/5. Additionally, hallmark gene sets frequently associated with senescence, such as interferon responses48, epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT)49, NF-κB signaling50, and the complement system, were significantly enriched in Inv3 and Inv7 (Supplementary Figure 1B). Collectively, these findings suggest that senescence is transiently induced during mammary gland involution, coinciding with the onset of tissue remodeling.

sec.title: Involution-associated senescence does not accumulate with age
sec.p: Senescent cells accumulate during aging in various tissues9. A recent study has reported that aged mammary stem/progenitor cells acquire a gene signature associated with cellular senescence51. We questioned whether senescent cells might accumulate in the mammary gland upon multiple pregnancies (multiparity). To address this question, we compared SA-βGal+ cells across several groups, including involuting MGs following the first pregnancy (1P-Inv5, ~3 months), resting mammary glands after one round of involution (1P-RS ~4 months), involuting MGs following multiparous glands (MP-Inv5, ~11 months, corresponding to approximately 35 years in humans), resting mammary glands post-MP (MP-RS ~12 months, corresponding to approximately 40 years in humans), and glands from nulliparous mice (O-virgin ~12 months) (Figure 1F). We observed a minor, non-significant increase in SA-βGal+ cells in involuting multiparous MGs (MP-Inv5) compared to 1P MGs (IP-Inv5) (Figure 1F). Furthermore, we detected negligible SA-βGal+ cells in mammary glands from one-year-old females, regardless of parity status. These findings suggest that the senescence program associated with involution does not accumulate or amplify with multiple pregnancies during reproductive aging.

sec.title: Alveolar luminal cells are the major senescent cell type
sec.p: To identify which cell types undergo senescence during MG involution, we employed C12FDG, a fluorogenic substrate for β-galactosidase 52, alongside cell-specific markers. Stromal cells were identified as CD31-, CD45-, CD24-, α6-; basal cells as CD31-, CD45-, CD24low, α6high; and luminal cells as CD31-, CD45-, CD24high, α6low. Using flow cytometry, we found that approximately 6% of stromal cells, 15% of basal cells, and 52% of luminal cells were C12FDG+ at Inv5 compared to Inv0 (Supplementary Figure 2B). Although our antibody panel could not distinguish alveolar epithelial cells from ductal epithelial cells, histological staining indicated that most SA-βGal+ cells are alveolar epithelial cells. Next, we conducted co-staining of SA-βGal with the basal cell marker Keratin 5 (Krt5) and the luminal cell marker Keratin 8 (Krt8) at Inv3. Consistently, we found that the majority of SA-βGal+ cells were Krt8+ alveolar luminal cells (Figure 2A), which are negative for both the apoptotic marker cleaved Caspase-3 (CC3) and the proliferation marker Ki67 (Supplementary Figure 2C & 2D). Together, our findings indicate that alveolar luminal cells are the primary senescent cell type during mammary gland involution.

sec.title: p16 upregulation, but not p21, is associated with mammary involution-induced senescence
sec.p: Interestingly, our bulk RNAseq analysis revealed upregulation of Cdkn2a, Rb1, Trp53, and various Trp53 target genes53, but not Cdkn1a, at Inv3 and Inv7 compared to Inv0 (Supplementary Figure 2E & 2F). To validate these findings, we performed qPCR on RNA extracted whole MGs at different involution time points. Results showed significant upregulation of both p16INK4a and p19Arf at Inv7, while p21 was transiently upregulated at Inv1 and returned to the basal levels by Inv3 (Figure 2B). We further investigated p16INK4a expression using a sensitive reporter mouse model, INKBRITE, where the p16INK4a promoter drives expression of multiple copies of H2B-GFP54. At Inv0, few GFP+ cells were observed within alveolar structure marked by Krt5 or in the stromal compartment (Figure.2C, upper panel). Importantly, at Inv7, a significantly higher proportion of GFP+ cells was detected, predominantly within the alveolar structures facing the lumen (Figure 2C, lower panel). Next, we examined whether involution-induced senescence was triggered by DNA damage. While we observed γH2AX+ cells at Inv3, predominantly in alveolar luminal cells, GFP+ and γH2AX+ cells were mutually exclusive (Figure 2D). These findings suggest that involution-induced senescence is linked to p16 upregulation, independent of p21, and occurs most likely independently of DNA damage.

We recently established a mammary organoid system that models mammary postnatal developmental stages including pregnancy, lactation, and involution ex vivo55. To test whether senescence is also induced during involution-like process in this organoid model, we performed whole-mount SAβGal staining on organoids cultured in either lactation-like medium (LM, Lac) or involution-like medium (BOM, Inv) (Figure 2E). Histological analysis revealed that involution-organoids were notably smaller than lactation-organoids, with significantly more SA-βGal+ cells in the involution-organoids (Figure 2F & Supplementary Figure 2,G). Consistently, qPCR analysis confirmed significant upregulation of p16 in involution-like organoids, with no significant change in p21 expression (Figure 2G). Thus, the organoid model supports the in vivo finding that p16, but not p21, is associated with senescence during involution, and organoid system can serve as a simplified ex vivo model to study involution-associated senescence.

sec.title: Systemic lactogenic hormones prevent senescence induction during involution
sec.p: Next, we investigated upstream signals regulating senescence induction during involution. Organoid experiments indicated that prolactin withdrawal triggers senescence (Figure 2E-G). To assess if systemic lactogenic signals are important for senescence induction in vivo, we sealed a set of teats of lactating mice to initiate local involution while maintaining systemic lactogenic hormone levels (Figure 3A & Supplementary Figure 3A). It is known that involution-associated programmed cell death (PCD) is triggered locally28, and consistent with previous findings, we observed distinct morphological differences between involuting and sealed MGs at the onset of irreversible involution (day 3, Figure 3B & Supplementary Figure 3C & 3D). The sealed MGs displayed intact alveolar structures without tissue remodeling, unlike the involuting MGs. Importantly, no SA-βGal+ cells or p16 upregulation were detected in sealed MGs compared to involuting MGs at Inv3 (Figure 3B, Supplementary Figure 3B). These results suggest that systemic lactogenic hormones withdrawal upon weaning is required for senescence induction during involution.

sec.title: p16-dependent senescence induction ensures involution dynamic
sec.p: To determine the functional relevance of senescence in mammary involution, we used both genetic and pharmaceutical approaches to perturb the senescence program. Firstly, we generated BlgCeTg/+;p16f/f mice, an alveolar luminal cell-specific p16 knockout model, to assess p16’s role in senescence during involution. In BlgCeTg/+;p16f/f mice, we observed a delayed onset of tissue remodeling compared to wild-type controls (Supplementary Figure 3E). Importantly, BlgCeTg/+;p16f/f MGs exhibited significantly fewer SAβGal+ cells at Inv5 compared to littermate controls (Figure 3D), though a minor, non-significant reduction in SAβGal+ cells was also observed at Inv4 (Supplementary Figure E). Hence, these findings demonstrate that alveolar luminal cell senescence during involution is p16 dependent.

Next, we evaluated the functional consequence of impaired senescence induction during MG involution, using alveolar size and adipocyte area as metrics to evaluate the involution kinetic. Interestingly, at Inv5, BlgCeTg/+;p16f/f MGs retained more epithelial structures and exhibited a reduced adipocyte area compared to controls (Figure 3E-G). Additionally, BlgCeTg/+;p16f/f MGs contained much more, but markedly smaller adipocytes than controls (Figure 3H-J), suggesting a link between reduced senescence and impaired adipocyte re-differentiation and hypotrophy. Collectively, these findings demonstrate that p16-dependent senescence is crucial for proper mammary gland involution.

sec.title: ABT-263 treatment delays mammary gland involution
sec.p: Next, we used ABT-26323,56, a BH3 mimetic targeting anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family proteins, to deplete senescent cells during involution. Mice were treated with ABT-263 daily for 3 days prior, and MGs were harvested at Inv3, Inv4, and Inv5 (Fig. 4A). Notably, ABT-263 treatment led to a significant increase in apoptotic (CC3+) cells and a decrease in SA-βGal+ cells, suggesting apoptosis was induced in senescent cells (Figure 4B & 4C). Notably, ABT-263 did not affect STAT3 activation, a key mediator of PCD during mammary involution57 (Supplementary Figure 4A). Consistent with the BlgCreTg/+; p16f/f mice, ABT-263-treated MGs exhibited delayed alveolar regression and reduced adipocyte refilling at Inv4 and Inv5 compared to controls (Figure 4D & 4E). However, unlike the BlgCreTg/+; p16f/f model, we observed no change in adipocyte numbers, except at Inv3 (Supplementary Figure 4C), indicating differences between senescence inhibition and senescent cell clearance. These findings indicate that ABT-263 effectively removes senescent cells and delays the involution process. Taken together, both genetic and pharmaceutical approaches demonstrated that senescence induction is important for proper MG involution.

sec.title: Senescent cells recruit macrophages during involution
sec.p: To gain insights on the role of senescence in involution, we further analyzed our bulk RNA-seq datasets. GSEA analysis revealed enriched biological processes related to immune cell chemotaxis and migration (Figure 5A and Figure 5B). We took advantage of the involuting organoid system to determine the expression of relevant genes (Figure 5C). The expression of Csn2, important for milk production, was significantly induced by prolactin and reduced after prolactin withdrawal55(Supplementary Figure 59A). Consistently, p16 expression was significantly upregulated post prolactin withdrawal (Supplementary Figure 5B). Interestingly, we found that chemokines critical for monocyte/macrophage recruitment and ECM modifiers important for tissue remodeling were upregulated in involuting organoids compared to lactational controls (Figure 5D, Supplementary Figure 5B), suggesting that senescent epithelial cells are at least one of the sources producing these factors.

Macrophages are known to infiltrate involuting MG at the onset of tissue remodeling phase, a process essential for adipocyte repopulation and involution progression58,59. Considering the intimate relationship between macrophage and senescent cells60, we hypothesized that senescent epithelial cells recruit macrophages during involution. Supporting this, we found significantly fewer CD45+ immune cells and macrophages (CD64+ or F4/80+) in ABT-263-treated involuting MGs compared to controls (Figure 5E, Supplementary Figure 5C-E). Consistently, BlgCreTg/+; p16f/f involuting MGs showed fewer F4/80+ macrophages than controls (Figure 5F). These data suggest that senescent epithelial cells play a key role in recruiting macrophages during involution to ensure proper involution dynamic.

sec.title: Involution associated senescence promotes postpartum tumorigenesis
sec.p: Next, we set to explore the potential implication of involution-associated senescence in breast cancer. Women diagnosed with breast cancer within five to ten years postpartum exhibit a worse prognosis compared to age-matched nulliparous women or those diagnosed during pregnancy independent of hormone receptor status12,41. It has been proposed that the involuting mammary gland microenvironment promotes breast cancer metastasis44,61,62. Given senescent cells can extensively rewire the microenvironment to influence cancer progression in a context-dependent manner 8,63–65, we investigated whether senescence associated with mammary gland involution contributes to a pro-tumorigenic microenvironment.

To test this hypothesis, we utilized the MMTV-neu mouse model (Figure 6A). Consistent with existing literature62, we observed that a single round of pregnancy and subsequent involution significantly reduced tumor latency (Figure 6B). Surprisingly, repeated rounds of pregnancy mitigated the impact of parity on tumorigenesis (Figure 6B). Previous studies suggest that concurrent pregnancy delays the involution process66. To examine whether concurrent pregnancy affects involution-associated senescence, we mated MMTV-neu mice and dispatched them into two groups randomly. We removed the male from the control group after confirming pregnancy (control group), while left the male with the other group of pregnant females (concurrent pregnancy group).

Upon delivery, all females from both groups established lactation successfully, and we confirmed that females kept with the males (concurrent pregnancy) conceived again during lactation. We then removed pups from both groups to initiate synchronized involution and collected mammary glands at Inv3 and Inv7 (Supplementary Figure 6A). Histological analysis and STAT3 activation confirmed a delayed involution process in the concurrently pregnant females (Supplementary Figure 6B & 6C)66. Notably, we observed a significant reduction in SA-βGal+ cells in the involuting mammary glands of concurrently pregnant females (Supplementary Figure 6D & 6E). Our animal records further indicated that the multiparous MMTV-neu mice remained pregnant during involution. Thus, we hypothesized that bypassing involution-associated senescence might underlie the diminished impact of parity on tumorigenesis. To test this hypothesis, we treated MMTV-neu mice with ABT-263 for two weeks at the onset of involution (Figure 6C). Importantly, ABT-263 treatment significantly delayed tumor latency in parous mice compared to controls (Figure 6D), supporting the notion that involution-associated senescence promotes mammary tumorigenesis.

sec.title: Involution-associated senescence promotes tumor plasticity via SASP
sec.p: Next, we sought to elucidate the mechanisms by which involution-induced senescence promotes tumorigenesis. Previously, we showed that senescence promotes cellular plasticity in the context of cellular reprogramming67,68, and the activation of Rank signaling induces senescence to promote mammary tumorigenesis69. Therefore, we investigated whether senescence promotes tumor plasticity by establishing a conditioned medium (CM)-based tumor organoid system. Specifically, we generated involuting organoids from both control and BlgCreTg/+;p16f/f mice, collecting CM every two days for three times after day 14 (day 14, day 16, and day 18) to culture 4T1 tumor organoids derived from virgin Balb/c hosts (Figure 6E). Notably, tumor organoids cultured with CM from BlgCreTg/+;p16f/f mice exhibited significantly fewer invasive events than those cultured with control CM (Figure 6F). These findings suggest that involution-associated senescence promotes tumor invasion in a paracrine manner.

sec.title: Involution associated senescence promotes mammary tumor metastasis in the lung
sec.p: Finally, to investigate whether involution associated senescence could promote the tumor metastatic potential in vivo, we adapted a postpartum breast cancer mouse model focused on the tumor-promoting effects of involution62. We injected 4T1 cells into both virgin and involuting (Inv2) Balb/c mice, treating half of the groups with ABT-263 as described above (Figure 6G). Importantly, we found that ABT-263 treatment significantly suppressed lung metastasis (Figure 6H & 6I). Notably, no difference was observed in the virgin groups, indicating that ABT-263 specifically targets senescent cells in the involuting microenvironment without affecting tumor cells directly (Figure 6I). Taken together, these data support our hypothesis that involution associated physiological senescence enhances the plasticity of tumor-initiating cells to facilitate tumor invasion and metastasis.
Collectively, our study uncovers a pivotal dual role for senescence during postpartum mammary gland involution, demonstrating its importance in both physiological tissue remodeling and tumorigenesis.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Here, we report that senescence is transiently induced during postpartum mammary gland involution, a physiological process critical for restoring mammary gland homeostasis after pregnancy. We identify that alveolar luminal cells are the primary cell type undergoing p16-dependent senescence, which is likely driven by systemic hormone withdrawal. Loss-of-function experiments demonstrate that senescence facilitates tissue remodeling processes to ensure proper involution. Unexpectedly, we also find that involution-associated senescence promotes PPBC progression by enhancing tumor-initiating cell plasticity through paracrine signaling. These findings reveal a previously unappreciated dual role for senescence in tissue repair and tumorigenesis, demonstrating how physiological senescence can be exploited by oncogenic events. This highlights the potential for targeting involution-associated senescence as a novel therapeutic strategy to mitigate postpartum breast cancer progression.

Involution-associated senescence shares notable parallels with senescence in decidual stromal cells of the cycling human endometrium70, which is required for successful implantation71. Both processes are triggered by fluctuation in female sex hormones, mediated by p53 and p16 upregulation, and play important roles in scarless tissue remodeling. However, their hormonal regulation differs. Brighton et al. showed that progesterone induces differentiation and senescence in human primary endometrial stromal cells during decidualization70, while in mammary gland, prolactin withdraw is required for senescence induction (Figure 2F, 2G and 3B). This context-dependent role of sex hormones underscores their importance as potential triggers of senescence. Interestingly, senescence induction in alveolar luminal cells appears to be DNA damage-independent (Figure 2D), consistent with development senescence16. Future work will be needed to delineate the molecular pathways that trigger mammary alveolar luminal cell senescence.

A recent study has reported that aged mammary gland stem cells exhibited senescence-like gene signature51. Curiously, our study showed that involution-associated senescent cells do not accumulate with age, which suggests that involution-associated senescence is a highly controlled and programmed process, distinct from the stochastic nature of ageing-associated senescence. In the future, it could be interesting to know whether senescent cells accumulate in the uterus during the premenopausal period.

Our RNA-seq analysis revealed that involution-associated senescence is linked to upregulation of Cdkn2a and Trp53. Notably, Trp53-/- and p19Arf-/- mice exhibit delayed mammary involution, highlighting the importance of these pathways in this process72. Interestingly, we did not observe a reduction in senescence burden or altered involution dynamics in Cdkn2a-/- mice (data not shown). However, acute deletion of p16 in alveolar luminal cells partially prevented senescence induction and impaired the involution process (Figure 3). These results suggest that potential compensatory mechanisms may obscure phenotypes in germ-line knockout models. It remains plausible that p19Arf or other members of the INK4 family also play critical roles in this process, warranting further investigation into their contributions.

To explore the functional relevance of senescence induction, we used both a genetically modified mouse model (BlgCre; p16f/f) and the senolytic compound ABT-263, which induces apoptosis in senescent cells. Both approaches significantly reduced senescent cell populations and delayed involution, notable differences were observed between the two strategies. In BlgCre; p16f/f mice, reduction in senescent cells and delayed involution became evident only at InvD5. In contrast, ABT-263-treated mice exhibited a reduction in senescence induction as early as InvD3, but this did not affect alveolar regression or adipocyte refilling until InvD4. These differences may be explained by the distinct mechanisms of action of the two approaches: the genetic model prevents only p16-dependent senescence, while ABT-263 actively removes all types of senescent cells through apoptosis. Intriguingly, we observed a significant increase in adipocyte numbers exclusively in BlgCre; p16f/f mice, suggesting that p16+ senescent cells might specifically impact adipogenesis.

Developmental and programmed senescence, such as those observed during embryonic development16,17,73, the female reproductive cycle70,71, and postpartum involution, including mammary gland and uterius74, occur within immune-privileged microenvironments. However, it remains unclear whether senescence actively establishes this immunosuppressive state. Our GSEA analysis revealed enrichment of pathways regulating immune cell chemotaxis, leading us to propose that senescent epithelial cells recruit macrophages during the irreversible phase of involution. Further characterization of the immune landscape will provide critical insights into the specific role of senescence in establishing immune suppression during postpartum tissue remodeling. Additionally, while both natural killer (NK) cells71 and macrophages74 are known to eliminate senescent cells in physiological contexts, it remains unknown which immune cells are required for regulating the fate of involution-associated senescence. Understanding these interactions will be pivotal in unraveling the immune-modulatory roles of senescence in postpartum tissue remodeling, which will have direct implications in tumorigenesis.

Finally, we demonstrated that physiological senescence program can be exploited by oncogenic process. In this study, we specifically focused on paracrine senescence in promoting tumor-initiating cells plasticity. Given the extensive body of research highlighting the distinctive features of involution41–43, it would be important to investigate whether and how senescence contributes to the establishment of a pro-tumorigenic microenvironment. Recent studies highlight shared immunosuppressive mechanisms between pregnancy and oncogenesis75, and senescent cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) have been shown to mediate immune suppression to facilitate cancer progression63,76. These findings suggest potential parallels between the roles of senescence in physiological tissue remodeling and tumorigenesis, warranting further investigation.

sec.title: Mice and experimental procedures
sec.p: Experiments involving animals were approved in accordance with French legislation in compliance with European Communities Council Directives (A 75-15-01-3) and the regulations of Institut Pasteur Animal Care Committees (CETEA). The study was performed by certified individuals and carried out in accordance with the principles of the Basel Declaration.

Wild-type inbred strain C57BL/6J mice were bred at the Monod Animal Facility of the Institut Pasteur. INKBRITE mice1 were kindly provided by Dr Peng (University of California, San Francisco) and bred in a C57BL6 genetic background. BlgCre mice2 were obtained from The Jackson Laboratory (strain #012620) and bred in a mixed genetic background C57BL6; 129. p16-floxed mice3 were obtained from the MMRRC (strain #043540-UNC) and bred in a mixed genetic background B6; 129S4. BlgCre mice were crossed with p16-floxed mice to delete p16 specifically in Blg expressing cells. There mice are named BlgCre; p16f/f in this manuscript. MMTV-neu mice4 were obtained from The Jackson Laboratory (strain #005038) and bred in a FVB/N genetic background. For the 4T1 tumor cells transplantation, Balb/c mice were obtained from Charles River Laboratory. All animals were bred from the Central Animal Facility of the Institut Pasteur.

sec.title: Kinetic
sec.p: Tissues from pubertal mice were collected at 6 weeks old; tissues from virgin mice were collected at 8-10 weeks old (Y-virgin) or 12-14 months old (O-virgin); tissues from pregnant mice were collected at p13.5 and p18.5; tissues from multiparous mice were collected at the resting stage from females coming from breeding cages, after 3-4 rounds of pregnancy. For the involution experiments, adult virgin females were mated between 8 to 10 weeks old. To homogenize lactation stimuli, litters were evenly distributed to 6 pups per female after birth and fed by the mother for 10 days. Then, pups were physically separated to allow a synchronized involution of mammary glands. The day of removal of the progeny was considered as the beginning of involution, also called Lac10 or Inv0. The involution process was let to progress from Inv0 to Inv28 or resting stage (RS).

sec.title: ABT treatment
sec.p: ABT-263 [Tebu #T2101]5, was initially resuspended in DMSO at 100mg/ml, aliquoted and stored at -20°C for <1 month. ABT-263 was then freshly diluted by adding forced feeding mixture (60% Phosal; 30% PEG400; 10% EtOH) of vehicle (same mix with DMSO only) upon use. Mice were force-fed by oral gavage daily with ABT-263 at 50mg/kg for 1 to 3 days before mammary glands harvesting or for 10-14 days in tumor development experiments.

sec.title: Sealing
sec.p: Teat sealing was performed as previously described6. Briefly, after delivery, females were allowed to lactate for 10 days. Hair remover was applied to clean the nipple area from mammary glands before sealing. After manually restraining the animal, a 2-3μl drop of veterinary tissue adhesive [3M Vetbond #1469C] was applied on the nipple and left to dry before the release of the mouse in the cage with the litter. The manipulation was repeated 3h later to ensure a full sealing of the nipple. Maintenance of lactation on counterpart open teats was checked every day. Mammary glands were harvested 2 or 3 days after teat closure.

sec.title: Concurrent pregnancy
sec.p: To allow a concurrent pregnancy, females were kept with males after delivery. Only females that were pregnant again the first week of lactation were considered for concurrent pregnancy experiments.

sec.title: Whole-mount analyses, histology and immunolabeling
sec.p: For morphological analyses, mammary fat pads were spread on glass slides and fixed overnight in a solution of methacarn (60% methanol; 30% chloroform; 10% acetic acid). Mammary glands were washed twice in EtOH 70%, once in H2O, and incubated overnight in Carmine Alum staining [Stem Cell Technologies #07070] at room temperature. Then, mammary glands were washed in H2O followed by EtOH 70% and processed for embedment in paraffin. During the second clearing with xylenes, pictures of whole mounts stained mammary glands were taken using a binocular magnifier.

For histological analyses, mammary glands, tumors, or organs were fixed overnight in Formalin (or metarcarn as previously described) and embedded in paraffin. 5mM-thick sections were cut and de-waxed for hematoxylin/eosin coloration or immunolabelling (immune-histo-chemistry IHC or immunofluorescence IF). When specified, an antigen retrieval was performed using a retriever [Electron Microscopy Sciences #2100]. For immunochemistry, an inhibition of endogenous peroxidase was performed using H2O2 1% during 10 min prior to a 1h blocking step. The co-staining with SAβGal (IHC) was performed using SAβGal staining of mammary gland samples. For immunofluorescence analyses on cryopreserved samples, slides of 10μm-thick OCT cryopreserved mammary glands were removed from -80°C storage and dried at room temperature for 30 min. Samples were fixed in a fixation solution of PFA 4% [Electron Microscopy Sciences #15714] in PBS at room temperature for 15 min before the IF (see below).
The primary antibodies used are listed below:

sec.title: Senescence-associated-b-galactosidase staining
sec.p: For senescence-associated-b-galactosidase staining in whole-mount (SAβGal staining), mammary glands or organoids were incubated in a fixation solution of PFA 2% [Electron Microscopy Sciences #15714] and glutaraldehyde 0.2% [Sigma #49629] in PBS at room temperature during respectively 30 min or 15 min, on a swing. After brief washes in PBS, mammary glands were incubated overnight (only 6 hours for the organoids) at 30°C in the SAβgal solution (see SAβgal staining section), followed by washes in PBS, and post-fixed during 8h in 10% formalin on a swing. Then, mammary glands were briefly washed in PBS, dehydrated and embedded in paraffin. Organoids were embedded in 3% low gelling temperature agarose. After solidification, samples were dehydrated before paraffin embedding. Tissue sections (5mM-thick) were then counterstained with Nuclear FastRed [Vector H-3403] for 2 to 5 min, dehydrated and mounted with Eukitt [Sigma Aldrich #49629] or used for IHC co-staining.

For senescence-associated-β-galactosidase staining on cryosections, sections of 10μm (cryopreserved mammary glands) in OCT [Leica #14020108926], were removed from -80°C storage and dried at room temperature for 30 min. Samples were fixed in a fixation solution of PFA 2% [Electron Microscopy Sciences #15714] and glutaraldehyde 0.2% [Sigma #49629] in PBS at room temperature during 15 min. After three PBS washes of 5 min, mammary glands were incubated 6h at 30°C in a SAβGal solution. After incubation, samples were washed in PBS, post-fixed in PFA 4% [Electron Microscopy Sciences #15714] for 15 min and washed again in PBS. Tissue sections were then counterstained with Nuclear FastRed [Vector #H-3403] for 2 to 5 min, dehydrated by one 5 min bath of EtOH 95% and two 5 min EtOH 100% baths before mounted with Eukitt [Sigma Aldrich #49629].

SAβGal solution contains: 40mM of citrate buffer pH 6.0 [VWR #28027; Sigma #C7129]; 5mM of K3Fe(CN)6 [Sigma #P8131]; 5mM of K4Fe(CN)6 [Sigma #P9387]; 2mM of MgCl2 [Sigma #M8266]; 150mM of NaCl [Sigma #31434]; 0.1% of NP40 [Sigma #I8896].; 0.5mg/mL of X-gal [Roche #10703729001] and ultrapure Milli-Q water.

sec.title: Isolation of primary mammary epithelial organoids
sec.p: Primary mammary organoids were prepared from a pool of thoracic and inguinal mammary glands (without visible lymph node) isolated from at least three 8-12 weeks old female mice as previously described7,8.

Briefly, the mice were euthanized by cervical dislocation or CO2 exposition. The mammary glands were removed and homogenously minced in approximately 1-mm3 pieces before being transferred to a 50-mL tube of digestion solution containing 2 mg/ml collagenase A (Roche, Cat#11088793001), 2 mg/ml trypsin (Dutcher Dominique, Cat#P10-022100), 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 5 μg/ml insulin (Sigma, Cat#I6634-100MG), 50 μg/mL gentamicin (Sigma, Cat#G1397) and 1x Glutamine (Gibco, Cat#35050-061) in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM)/F12 (Gibco, Cat#21331-020), and incubated for 30-40 min at 37°C with shaking at 100 rpm.

Resulting pellets of digested samples were centrifuged and successively treated with solutions of 100μg/mL DNAseI (Sigma, Cat#D4527-40KU) for 3-5 min at RT and 0.5 mg/ml dispase II (Roche, Cat#13 75 2000) and exposed to five rounds of differential centrifugation at 450 × g for 10 s, which resulted in separation of epithelial (organoid) and stromal fractions. The organoids were resuspended in basal organoid medium (BOM) containing 1x Glutamine, 1x Insulin-Transferrin-Selenium (Gibco, Cat#41400-045) and 1x penicillin/streptomycin (Gibco, Cat#15140-122) in DMEM/F12 and kept on ice for quantification on a slide.

sec.title: Isolation and culture
sec.p: Freshly isolated primary mammary organoids were resuspended in an appropriate volume of growth factor reduced Matrigel (BD Biosciences, Cat# 354230) and plated. To prepare the cell culture plate, use a small volume of Matrigel (10-20 μL per well) to cover the central part of the bottom of wells of a 24-well cell culture plate. Incubate the plate at 37°C for 15 min. Then, seed respectively 200 or 4-500 organoids per drop for histology and gene expression analysis (50μL of Matrigel per drop). Incubate the plate for 30-60 min in an incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2. Finally, add pre-warmed basal organoid medium (BOM) in each well to cover Matrigel drop. For organoids growing, add 2.5nM of FGF2 (Gibco, Cat#PM60034) in BOM medium for 6 days. Change medium every 3 days. To induce lactogenic differentiation, add 1 μg/mL prolactin (Sigma, Cat#SRP4688) + 1 μg/mL hydrocortisone (Sigma, Cat#H6909) in BOM medium during 4 to 14 days. Change lactogenic medium every 2 days. To induce involution-like process, we cultivate organoids only in BOM and change the medium every 2 days.

sec.title: Conditional media collection
sec.p: For tumor invasion experiments, conditioned medium, containing soluble proteins and exosomes /extracellular vesicles (EVs), was collected from organoid culture at d16 and d18 of involution-like process from BlgCre+/+; p16f/f (control) and BlgCreTg/+; p16f/f organoids. After 5min of centrifugation at 1000rpm to acquire the supernatant, aliquoted conditioned media were stored at -20°C.

sec.title: Isolation and culture of mammary tumor organoids
Isolation
sec.p: Primary mammary tumor organoids were prepared from a tumor, originated from transplanted 4T1 cells in a nulliparous Balb/c mouse, as previously described9.

Briefly, the transplanted Balb/c mice were euthanized by cervical dislocation or CO2 exposition. The mammary tumor was removed and homogenously minced in approximately 1-mm3 pieces before being transferred to a 50-mL tube of digestion solution containing 2 mg/ml collagenase A (Roche, Cat#11088793001), 2 mg/ml trypsin (Dutcher Dominique, Cat#P10-022100), 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 5 μg/ml insulin (Sigma, Cat#I6634-100MG), 50 μg/mL gentamicin (Sigma, Cat#G1397) and 1x Glutamine (Gibco, Cat#35050-061) in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM)/F12 (Gibco, Cat#21331-020), and incubated for 1h at 37°C with shaking at 180 rpm.

Resulting pellets of digested samples were centrifuged and treated with solution of 2 U/μL of DNAseI (Sigma, Cat#D4527-40KU) for 3-5 min at RT and exposed to four rounds of differential centrifugation at 400 × g for 3 s, which resulted in separation of epithelial (organoid) and stromal fractions. The organoids were resuspended in BOM and counted.

sec.title: Culture
sec.p: Freshly isolated mammary tumor organoids were resuspended in an appropriate volume of 1:1 growth factor reduced Matrigel (BD Biosciences, Cat# 354230) and Collagen Type I (Corning, Cat#354236) and plated. To prepare the cell culture plate, a small volume of Matrigel (10-20 μL per well) was used to cover the central part of the bottom of wells of a 24-well cell culture plate. The plate was incubated at 37°C for 15 min. Then, 100 organoids per drop were for time-lapse imaging (50μL of the mix of Matrigel/Collagen I per drop). The plate was incubated for 30-60 min in an incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2 to allow the polymerization of the Matrigel/Collagen I drops. Finally, pre-warmed CM, collected from primary organoid culture at d16 of involution-like process from BlgCre+/+; p16f/f (control) and BlgCreTg/+; p16f/f organoids, complemented with 2.5nM of FGF2 (Gibco, Cat#PM60034) was added in each well to cover Matrigel/Collagen I drop for 4 days.

sec.title: RNA isolation and real-time quantitative PCR
sec.p: Total RNA from mammary tissues or organoids samples were extracted respectively with Trizol Reagent [Invitrogen #15596026] or RNeasy Micro Kit (Qiagen) following manufacturer’s instructions. Reverse transcription was performed using High-capacity cDNA reverse transcription kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Quantitative real-time PCR was performed using 5 ng cDNA, 5 pmol of the forward and reverse gene-specific primers each in Light Cycler SYBR Green I Master mix (Roche) on LightCycler 480 II (Roche). All reactions were performed at least in duplicates and in a total of at least three independent assays. Relative gene expression was calculated using the ΔΔCt method and the values were normalized to housekeeping gene Gapdh. The primers of following sequences (5’-3’) were used:

sec.title: Quality Control and Preprocessing
sec.p: Raw sequencing reads were subjected to quality control using FastQC (v0.11.9). Low-quality bases and adapter sequences were trimmed using TrimGalore (v0.6.7) with the following parameters: --stringency 4. Reads passing the quality filters were retained for further analysis.

sec.title: Quantification of Gene Expression
sec.p: Gene expression levels were quantified using RSEM (v1.3.3) against the Mus musculus reference genome GRCm39.

sec.title: Differential Gene Expression Analysis
sec.p: Differential expression analysis was performed using edgeR 3.28.110 in R 3.5 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria). Genes with an adjusted p-value (FDR using Benjamini-Hochberg method) < 0.05 and an |log2(fold change)| > 1 were considered significantly differentially expressed.

sec.title: Functional Enrichment Analysis
sec.p: To identify enriched biological pathways, normalized counts were subjected to pathway enrichment analysis via Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) using the official GSEA software v4.3.3 from the Broad Institute11,12. 1000 permutations using the “gene_set” permutation type parameter were performed for the HALLMARK13, the Gene Ontology – Biological Process14,15, and the SAUL_SEN_MAYO16 gene sets. All gene sets were retrieved from the mouse Molecular Signatures Database17. Genes sets with an adjusted p-value (FDR) < 0.05 and an |Normalized Enrichment Score| > 1 were considered significantly different.

sec.title: Visualization and Data Interpretation
sec.p: Enrichment plots were generated by the GSEA software11,18 using the parameters described above. Principal component analysis (PCA) plot for the first two principal components and bar plots for significant HALLMARK pathways were generated using ggplot2 v2.1.0 (Wickham. 2016, Springer-Verlag New York) in R 3.5 (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria). The heatmaps were manually redrawn in Excel (Microsoft Corporation. 2018, Microsoft Excel) to visualize the core enriched genes, using relative expression values for better clarity and presentation.

sec.title: Primary mammary epithelial cells preparation and flow cytometry analysis
Mammary epithelial cells isolation
sec.p: To isolate mammary epithelial cells, mammary fat pads from Lac10 (or Inv0) and Inv5 females were collected and mechanically dissociated with scissors and scalpels before an enzymatic digestion for 1h30 at 37°C, shaking 140rpm, in a solution containing 3mg/mL Collagenase A [Roche #10103586001]; 100U/mL Hyaluronidase [Sigma #H3884] in CO2-independent medium [Gibco #18045-054], completed with 5% FBS, 2mM L-glutamine [Sigma Aldrich #G5792] and 100 U/mL of penicillin + 100 μg/mL of streptomycin [Gibco, #15140-122]. Digested tissues were centrifuged 5 min at 1100 rpm and the supernatant was discarded. After a wash with CO2-independent medium and a centrifugation, each pellet was resuspended with 2mL of prewarmed PBS + 0.25% trypsin [Dutscher #P10-022100] and 0.1% EDTA Versen [Biochrom #L2113], for 1 min at RT. After a second wash in CO2-independent medium + 5% FBS and a centrifugation, each pellet was resuspended in 2ml of CO2-independent medium + 5% FBS containing 5mg/mL of dispase II [Roche #13752000] and 0.1mg/mL of DNAse I [Sigma Aldrich #D4527-40KU], and incubated 5 min at 37°C. After a third wash in CO2-independent medium + 5% FBS and a centrifugation, pellets were resuspended in 2mL of cold ammonium chloride solution [Stem Cell Technologies #07800] and immediately centrifuged. After a resuspension in CO2-independent medium, cell solution was filtered through a nylon mesh cell strainer with 40μm pores before immunolabeling and cell sorting.

sec.title: Immunolabelling
sec.p: Freshly dissociated mammary cells were incubated at 4°C for 30min with antibodies. The following conjugated antibodies were used: anti-CD45-APC 1:100 [Biolegend #103112, clone 30-F11]; anti-CD31-APC 1:100 [Biolegend #102510, clone MEC13.3]; anti-CD24-BV421 1:50 [Biolegend #101826, clone M1/69]; anti-α6-PE.Cy7 1:50 [Biolegend #313622, clone GoH3]; anti-CD64-Alexa Fluor 647 1:100 [BD Pharmingen #558539, clone X54-5/7.1].
After incubation, cells were washed twice with CO2-independent medium. Labeled cells were sorted using a MoFlo Astrios EQ [Beckman Coulter] and data were analyzed with FlowJo software.

sec.title: C12FDG staining
sec.p: Before immunolabeling, C12FDG staining was performed on isolated mammary cell suspension following the C12FDG protocol previously described to stain senescent cells19. Following suppliers’ guidelines, Bafilomycin A1 [Tebu #21910-2060] was resuspended in DMSO to a concentration of 0.1mM and stored at -20°C and C12FDG [Fisher #11590276] was resuspended in DMSO at a concentration of 20mM and stored at -20°C. After mammary cells dissociation, pellets of isolated cells were resuspended into 1mL of CO2-independent medium [Gibco #18045-054]. To neutralize acidic pH of lysosomes, cells were treated with 100nM of Bafilomycin A1 for 1h at 37°C, 5% CO2. Upon use, C12FDG 20mM stock was first diluted with DMSO to a temporary stock of 2mM in fresh culture media and added to the cell solution at a concentration of 33µM. Cells were incubated 2h at 37°C, 5% CO2 (Eppendorf tubes were manually inverted every 30 min to homogenize the solution). After incubation, cells were washed twice with CO2-independent medium and centrifuged 5 min at 1100 rpm. Resuspended pellets were then stained with antibodies compatible with the green FITC-emitted signal (wavelength 488) from C12FDG.

sec.title: 4T1 transplantation experiment
sec.p: For the tumor transplantation experiment, 10.000 4T1 cells were injected (50mL) subcutaneously into the mammary fat pad of Virgin or Involuted day 2 (Inv2) Balb/c females. 4T1 cells were resuspended in PBS. Mice were monitored twice a week and harvested 4 weeks after transplantation.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using the GraphPad Prism software, statistical test used is specified in figure legend. * p < 0.05, ** p < 0.01, *** p < 0.001, **** p < 0.0001. The number of independent biological replicates is indicated as n.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We are grateful to the Central Animal Facility, Cytometry Platform, and Bioinformatics and Biostatistics Hub of Institut Pasteur. This work was funded by Institut Pasteur, Centre National pour la Recherche Scientific and the Agence Nationale de la Recherche (Laboratoire d’Excellence Revive, Investissement d’Avenir; ANR-10-LABX-73), and Foundation ARC (PJA 20181208231). Work in the HL laboratory was also funded by Agence Nationale de la Recherche (ANR-16-CE13-0017, ANR-21-CE13-0006-01, ANR-22-CE16-0015-03), and AFMTELETHON (22403). Marielle Saclier is recipient of Revive postdoc fellowship, Elsa Charifou and Jeremy Chantrel are recipient of FRM 4th PhD fellowships, Jeremy Chantrel’ PhD is funded by DIM Longévité et vieillissement PhD fellowship. Shuoyang Wang and Laurianne Temime were awarded Institut Pasteur Cancer Initiative M2 fellowship.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: The bulk RNA sequencing data have been deposited at Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO, access number GSE285005) and will be publicly available as of the date of publication. Source data supporting the findings of this study are provided with this paper. Additional data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.

fn.p: A.C, E.C, L.D performed most of the experimental work, contributed to most of experimental design, data analysis, and discussions. SY. W, L.T, and M.S made critical experimental contributions. SX. W, and J.C performed bioinformatic analysis. H.L. supervised the study, designed the experiments and interpreted the data together with A.C, and wrote the manuscript. All authors discussed the results and commented on the manuscript. The authors declare no competing financial interests with this paper.

caption.title: Transient induction of senescence during mammary gland involution
caption.p: A. Experimental design highlighting the time points of mammary glands collection at: puberty (6 weeks), adult virgin (10 weeks), pregnancy (p13.5, p18.5), lactation (10 days - Lac10/Inv0), involution after 1, 3, 7, 14 and 28 days/resting stage (Inv1, Inv2, Inv3, Inv7, Inv14, and Inv28/RS).
B-C. SAβgal staining during MG developmental stages. Scale bar: 100μm.
D. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) of transcriptomes from mammary glands collected at Inv0, Inv3, Inv7 samples (n=3 for each).
E. GSEA enrichment plots. Reference gene set: SEN_MAYO.

F. SAβgal staining of mammary gland during the 1st involution (1P-Inv5), after at least 3 rounds of reproductive cycles (MP-Inv5 and MP-RS), or in old virgin females (12 months). Scale bar: 100μm (left panel). Quantification of SAβgal cells related to total number of cells at different timepoints of mammary gland stage (right panel), Y-Virgin n=4 ; Lac10 n=2 ; 1P-Inv5 n=7 ; 1P-RS n=4 ; MP-Inv5 n=3 ; MP-RS n=4 ; O-Virgin n=3. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation.

caption.title: Alveolar luminal cells are the major senescent cell type
caption.p: A. Representative pictures of co-staining SAβGal with Krt5 or Krt8 markers on WT mammary glands from Inv3 females (n=2). Scale bar: 100μm

B. qPCR analysis of p16, p19 and p21 genes from mammary glands collected from Inv0 to Inv28 (n=4 for each timepoint). Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation relative to Inv0. Two-way ANOVAs were performed. p-values *<0.05, **<0.01, ****<0.0001.
C. Representative pictures of co-staining of GFP with Krt5 on INKBRITE involuting mammary gland from Inv0 (n=4) and Inv7 (n=3). Scale bar: 50μm. Quantification represents p16INKBRITE-GFP+ cells.
D. Representative pictures of co-staining of GFP with Krt5 and gH2AX on INKBRITE involuting mammary gland from Inv0 (n=4) and Inv3 (n=4). Scale bar: 100μm
E. Experimental design of ex vivo culture of organoids.
F. SAβGal staining of involuting organoids from involuting (BOM, d18) and lactation control (LM, d18) (n=3). Scale bar: 100μm

G. qPCR analysis of p16 and p21 of organoids from involution-like and lactation-like process. n=3 biological replicates. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. One-way ANOVAs were performed. p-values **<0.01, ***<0.001.

caption.title: Impaired senescence delays mammary gland involution
caption.p: A. Experimental design of involuting (blue) or teat sealed (red) mammary glands, while other mammary glands are maintained in lactation. Mammary glands were collected 3 days after sealing and compared with mammary glands from mice undergoing normal involution.

B. Representative pictures of whole mount carmine and SAβGal staining from involuting or sealed mammary glands at day 3, on cryosections, counterstained with FastRed. Scale bar: 100μm. Automatic quantifications of SAβGal staining at day 3, from involuting (black, n=2) or sealed (red, n=3) mammary glands. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation.
C. Experimental design of experiment with BlgCre; p16f/f mice.

D. Representative pictures of SAαGal staining (left panel) from Blg+/+; p16f/f or BlgTg/+; p16f/f mammary glands at Inv5, on cryosections, counterstained with FastRed. Scale bar: 100μm. Automatic quantification of SAβGal staining (right panel), Blg+/+; p16f/f n=7 ; BlgTg/+; p16f/f n=9. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-test was performed. p-values *<0.05.

E. Representative pictures of α-SMA staining (left panel) from Blg+/+; p16f/f or BlgTg/+; p16f/f mammary glands at Inv5. Scale bar: 100μm. Quantification of remaining epithelium (right panel), Blg+/+; p16f/f n=9 ; BlgTg/+; p16f/f n=12. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-test was performed. p-values *<0.05.
F. Representative pictures of perilipin staining from Blg+/+; p16f/f or BlgTg/+; p16f/f mammary glands at Inv5. Scale bar: 100μm.

G-I. Quantification of adipose tissue proportion (H), number of adipocytes per unit area (I), and average of adipocyte area per unit area (J), n=3 mice per group. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-test was performed. p-values *<0.05, **<0.01.
J. Distribution of adipocytes size from Blg+/+; p16f/f or BlgTg/+; p16f/f mammary glands at Inv5, n=3 mice per group. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation.

caption.title: ABT-263 treatment delays mammary gland involution
caption.p: A. Experimental design of in vivo treatment with ABT-263 at 50mg.kg-1.day-1 or vehicle. Mice were force-fed every day for 3 days prior to mammary gland collection at Inv3, Inv4 or Inv5.

B-C. Representative pictures of mammary gland sections from control or ABT-263 treated mice at Inv5, respectively stained for cleaved-caspase 3 (CC3) (B) and SAβGal on cryosection (C). Scale bar: 100μm. Quantifications of CC3 (B) and SAβGal staining (C). CC3 staining: Control n=4; ABT-263 n=6. SAβGal staining: Control n=10; ABT-263 n=8. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-tests were performed to analyze the effect of ABT-263 treatment respectively on the number of CC3+ or SAβGal+ cells. p-values **<0.01, ****<0.0001.

D-E. Representative pictures of mammary gland sections from control or ABT-263 treated mice at Inv3 to Inv5, respectively stained for α-SMA (upper panels), or Perilipin (lower panels). Scale bar: 100μm. Quantifications (right panels) for remaining epithelium and proportion of adipose tissue in percentage. α-SMA staining: Inv3/Inv4 n=5 for each group; Inv5 Control n=4, Inv5 ABT-263 n=6. Perilipin staining: Inv3 n=5 for each group; Inv4/Inv5 Control n=4, Inv4/Inv5 ABT-263 n=5. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-tests were performed. p-values *<0.05.

caption.title: Involution-induced senescence is required for macrophage recruitment
caption.p: A. GSEA analysis of GO-Biological Processes, top 20 enriched pathways.
B. GSEA enrichment plots. Reference gene set: GOBP_MONOCYTE_CHEMOTAXIS (upper panel) and GOBP_MACROPAGE_MIGRATION (lower panel).

C. Design of the organoids culture experiment. d0 to d6: FGF2 treatment to induce growth of organoids. d6 to d10: addition of lactogenic medium (LM) to mimic lactation. d10 to d18: Basic organoid medium (BOM) to mimic involution.
D. qPCR analysis of Ccl2, IL6, Csf1, Cxcl1, Cxcl5 genes from mammary organoids collected at d14 and d18 relative to d10. n=4 for each timepoint. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation.

E. Representative pictures of mammary gland sections from control or ABT-263 treated mice at Inv5, stained for F4/80 and its quantification. n=4 mice per group. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Mann-Whitney test was performed. p-values *<0.05. Scale bar: 50μm

F. Representative pictures of mammary gland sections from Blg+/+; p16f/f or BlgTg/+; p16f/f mice at Inv5, stained for F4/80 and its quantification. n=4 mice per group. Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation. Unpaired t-test was performed. p-values **<0.01. Scale bar: 50μm.

caption.title: Involution-induced senescence promotes postpartum tumorigenesis
caption.p: A. Experimental design of in vivo experiment with MMTV-neu mice. Mice were mated at the age of 10-12 weeks and allowed to go to lactation and natural involution, 1 to 3-4 times (called 1P or 3-4P for the number of pregnancies). Part of the littermate were maintained virgin to compare the tumor free latency.

B. Tumor free latency curve comparing Virgin vs. 1 pregnancy (1P) vs. 3-4 pregnancies (3-4P) from the first date of delivery used as starting point for the virgin littermate. n=20 for virgin; n=9 for 1P; n=6 for 3-4P. Curve comparison Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test was performed. p-value ****<0.0001 (Virgin vs. 1P); p-value=0.0002 (3-4P vs 1P).

C. Experimental design of in vivo experiment with MMTV-neu mice treated with ABT-263 at 50mg.kg-1.day-1 or vehicle. Mice were force-fed every day for 2 weeks following synchronized involution and tumor development was monitored every week.

D. Tumor free latency curve comparing 1 pregnancy + Vehicle (1P +Veh) vs. 1 pregnancy + ABT-263 (1P +ABT-263) from the date of delivery used as starting point. n=13 for 1P +Veh; n=10 for 1P +ABT-263. Curve comparison (Gehan-Breslow-Wilcoxon test) was performed. p-value *<0.0118.

E. Experimental design of in vitro experiment. After collection, conditional media from Blg+; p16f/f or BlgTg; p16f/f was used to cultivate organoids isolated from 4T1 tumor (transplantation in virgin balb/c females).

F. Representative brightfield pictures of tumor organoids growing from d0 to d4 (right panel). Quantification of invasion event per organoid at d4 (left panel), n=20 tumor organoids per condition. Unpaired t-tests were performed. p-values **<0.01.

G. Experimental design of in vivo experiment for 4T1 tumor cells transplantation in Balb/c mice treated with ABT-263 at 50mg.kg-1.day-1 or vehicle. Mice were injected when virgin or at day 2 of involution.
H. Representative pictures of lung sections from control or ABT-263 treated mice 4 weeks after transplantation, stained for hematoxylin and eosin. Scale bar: 1mm.
I. Diagram of lung metastasis frequency in control or ABT-263 treated mice 4 weeks after transplantation. n=6 for Virgin +Veh; n=6 for Virgin +ABT-263; n=5 for Inv2 +Veh; n=6 for Inv2 +ABT-263.
